title: For Sale:  9mm Lugar Tec 9
location: Mobile Hwy 1/2 mile west of W street, Pensacola, Florida
postcontent:
The TEC-9 was produced from 1985 to 1994.
 Intratec rebranded a variant of the TEC-9 as the TEC-DC9 from 1990 to 1994 (DC standing for "Designed for California"). The most noticeable external difference between the TEC-9 and the later TEC-DC9 is that rings to hold the sling were moved from the side of the gun with the cocking handle, to a removable stamped metal clip in the back of the gun. The TEC-9 and TEC-DC9 are otherwise identical.  In 2001, the company went out of business and production of the AB-10 model ceased.

This listing is for THREE Magazines; Buyers, however, may take any number of additional ones at the same per-mag price and with no additional shipping charges. Here are genuine factory Glock magazines to fit the Model 22 Pistol in .40 S&W Caliber. They will also fit models 23 and 27 with extra capacity but some protrusion; and of course they work just fine in the Glocks 31, 32 and 33 chambered in .357 Sig caliber since the case heads are the same for the two calibers. These magazines free-fall like they’re supposed to; lock the slide back like they’re supposed to; and most important, feed reliably. Manufacturer is Glock gmbh of Deutsche-Wagram, Austria. Importer is Glock, Inc., of Smyrna, GA. Construction is classic polymer body with steel inner lining, and visible loading ports so the operator can check round count.  Each magazine holds 15 rounds of .357 Sig or .40 S&W Caliber Ammunition. These are Third Generation magazines, and they will not work in a Generation 4 Glock set up for a Left Hand shooter. They will work just fine on any Glock set on Right Hand Shooter. Some of these are LE Marked, manufactured prior to 2004 when a certain Federal Statute sunset. Most of the parent pistols were manufactured in 2007. They served and protected our fellow citizens in Massachusetts with Lynn Police Department. Insertion and ejection streaking is moderate, and all of them are well maintained. Replacement pricing  on these in our area is upwards of $40 apiece, and many times they’re hard to come by even at those prices. Our Single Mag price is $25. We’re offering these excellent magazines, however, in lots of 3 or more at only $19 each. Own 3			for only	$ 57.00.	Not for sale to civilian residents of California, Connecticut, District of Colombia, Hawaii, Maryland, Massachusetts, New York, or any other jurisdiction where 15 round magazines are restricted to Law Enforcement only.  

Grips, Magazines, Slings, Holsters, Scopes, Mounts, Parts & Most any small light items,   entire accessory orders only $10.00 total shipping no matter how many a person buys. $10.00 for an entire order, Not $10.00 per item or anything of the sort. $20 Flat Fee on magazine orders to Alaska, Hawaii, or Puerto Rico, and gun parts to PR civilians must ship to an FFL. Magazines and any small light non-gun items ride free with ammo orders. We accept checks with no more than 7 days hold. With the introduction of the P938, SIG SAUER now offers the ballistic advantage of the 9mm cartridge in a platform similar in size to the best-selling P238 pistol. A single-action-only trigger, coupled with full-size SIGLITE® Night Sights makes the P938 handle like a much larger pistol, yet is still easy to carry concealed.

As near new as a used gun can be Beretta 92F. VERY reliable, smooth as butter(what else, it's a Beretta). Love this sidearm, but have too many so this one is being cut. I just don't carry it as often as I do the others. This gun has never had any issues, failure to feed or any other failures. What can I say about a Beretta 92? They are reknown world wide for rock solid reliability. Cash price is firm. I "might" consider trades. 

This comes with original case, houge & original grips, two original Beretta 15 round mags, paperwork, as well as laser box, and paperwork & original parts the laser replaces, & Bull Dog holster.

title: For Sale:  1915 Spanish Ruby
location: Mobile Hwy 1/2 mile west of W street, Pensacola, Florida
postcontent:
In 1914, just before the start of the First World War, Gabilondo started manufacture of a sturdy self-loading pistol based on the Browning Model 1903 and chambered for the 7.65mm Browning/.32 ACP cartridge. Unusually for the time, the magazine capacity was nine shots instead of the usual six or seven. The pistol was intended for export to the Americas, and despite the small calibre it was designed with military and police sales in mind. Other Spanish manufacturers had copied the Browning since around 1905. The Ruby, apart from the extended magazine appears to be a direct copy of a pistol called the "Victoria" made by Esperanza and Unceta. This pistol used features patented by Pedro Careaga in 1911, and by the Esperanza and Unceta company in 1912. These patents may have covered the frame-mounted safety (instead of a grip safety), and an internal striker (instead of a hammer)
Price Reduction was $375.00 Now Reduced

title: For Sale:  3 caliber set Hammerli (SIG) P240  22/.32/38
location: Far NE IL, Illinois, United States
postcontent:
Hammerli P240, matching SNs in the .38 unit, SN matched Box.  At this price, 2 magazines in each caliber, free shipping.  OEM manual included, and "tool kit".

"Close" offers considered .  Also one P240 frame only can be made available (no upper section) is available, which can be used with the complete set to end up with 2 simultaneously useful guns.

The gun or gun and extra frame are available with the "solid" drip original to the gun shown, or with a number of other fixed and adjustable grip options, or a fixed LH grip (size L).  In general, the non-adjustable target grips are better, and the one on the gun is perfection in reshaping, if it fits your hand.  Grip can be selected from other fixed grip sizes to fit, or an adjustable one in NOS condition provided.

This gun is NOT NOT NOT for someone who ones a "pinup" to place on a self and never use.  It has use marks, the .32 upper section is NOS but has some scratches thanks to US customs, and the .22 section (no serial number) has some minimal wear from the proof testing (most likely).  It IS IS IS for someone who wants accuracy in the 38 that is better than the more recent P240 upper sections, and accuracy in the .32 and .22 upper sections that is the equal of the more recent guns. It also is for the collector who wants the EARLY version of the P240 (see below).

The .38 upper section (SN matched to the frame) is one of the very rare early guns, with a large interlocking key welded onto the barrel, for more precise and tighter lockup with the upper section and frame.  Due to manufacturing expense, this was dropped in the later models and the Sig Sauer pistol line in general.  It does give superior accuracy however, especially as the gun warms up after the first 5 shots.

The .32 upper section is typical accuracy for this gun.  These are excellent but not as accurate as the SAKO due to a slower twist rate.  Upper sections and magazines NOT sold separately, but complete .32 guns with matched SNs are available, with or without box.

For those preferring a gun of similar accuracy but lower price, the GSP in .32 is an excellent alternative.  I have several available.  For those wanting higher quality and higher price is ok, a SAKO TriAce also is available in .22/.32.

For a more complete catalogue raisonne (selection guide and discussion as well as availability catalog), please email.  The SAKO is not in the catalogs, so inquire separately about that one.

The grip on this gun is fitted to absolute perfection for hand size 3.4-3.5". It can be enlarged slightly, or adjusted for shorter fingers by additional cutting. The current fitting on it, however, is one of the most precise and expert that I've ever ever ever seen. Even the left panel has been sculpted to match the right side artistically, or perhaps for 2 handed use.

I have up for sale a used Les Baer Shooting USA .45cal 1911 style pistol.  This pistol is used, but still veeerrry tight.  I acquired it in a trade and took it apart to clean it. One of the Kimpro mags is missing a screw on the floor plate.  It also comes with a Safariland nylon pistol case that has a pocket for 2 handguns and external magazine pouches.  It has very thick padding as well.  It also has the Les Baer patch, DVD, Sigarms 1911 plastic paddle holster, & original wood grips.  The grips on it now are black G10 type grips with torx head screws.  The knurling on the front and back straps is 30LPI and is very well done.  Everything about this pistol says quality.

The trigger on this gun is outstanding and the adjustable sights are as well.

title: For Sale:  Springfield Armory Custom Shop 5" "Special Cavalry" 1911
postcontent:
I took this in on trade from a US Army Cavalry officer who had this pistol custom built as an updated edition of a traditional 1911 USGI Sidearm. I already own a TRP Operator with a rail. If I didn't use the rail, I would definitely be keeping this custom shop pistol instead!

Springfield Armory Custom Shop 1911 - "Special Cavalry" - Custom Carry 1911-A1.
The pistol is basically a cross between the FBI's HRT Pro model and a TRP Operator with some very minor changes, most noticeably from the Pro, the addition of the lanyard loop on the MSH and the undercut triggerguard.

-Full size 5" 1911 built off a National Match frame and matching slide
-SS match barrel and bushing.
-20 LPI checkering on the front strap and MSH
-"Colt Style" high undercut triggerguard
-S&A magwell MSH with USGI-Style lanyard loop
-Wilson Ambidextrous Safety
-Novak brand (not SA "knockoffs") low-mount night sights with Trijicon tritium
-4.5lb trigger pull
-Custom Shop "memory bump" grip safety
-Mag well blended to Frame
-Armory Coat
-GI Guide Rod/Recoil System
-3 wilson 47D Mags

Markings:
Springfield Custom engraving (right side slide)
"Nancy Jane" Pistol's name engraving
"SPECIAL CAVALRY" "model" name engraving

This pistol is truly unique and she shoots beautifully, as you'd expect with a professionally built custom shop gun. Very few rounds fired through this pistol (250 - 50 from me, and 200 from the previous owner) - there is a marks from being dropped once (d'oh!) on the end of the rear sight (see picture) but no [typical] idiot mark or holster or hard use wear. I will also include a spare Novak cut rear night sight should you feel so inclined to swap the rear sight.

The HRT Pro model typically sells for $3,000 and the Custom Carry 1911-A1's generally go for a little less. This is your chance to get a custom shop pistol for slightly more than you'd pay for a TRP Operator. Invoice on this pistol was ~$2200, and custom shop builds have gone up in both price and wait time since that time.

Trades:
LWRC SPR, LMT MRP, or other high end AR platform Piston rifle, etc.
Tavor
SCAR
SOCOM II

Something in .50 BMG

title: For Sale:  FNH CZ Model 27 WW2 German Pistol Nazi Marking
postcontent:
This gun was made under German occupation, original slide legend was removed and serial number with Waffenampt were added to top of slide. Frame and slide match, magazine is original and marked, grips are nice and solid with slight wear. Safety and action are working. Have fired on various occasions, tested works well. Could clean up nicely, still some good bluing noticeable. Wanting $350 though will consider other offers.

Gun History:
Late WWII Nazi pistol produced for the Waffenamt (German Army Weapons Agency) at the CZ factory in Prague, probably around 1944. The Modell 27 was adopted by the Czech military in 1927 and continued in production until after the war. Waa76 is the Third Reich inspection mark for the CZ factory. The eagle-over-swastika stamp is a Nazi military test proof. "fnh" was the German ordinance code for the Prague factory where it was produced. Those obviously date it during the war after German conquest of Czechoslovakia, but before the Russkies kicked them out in 1945. And the serial number suggests late in the war, because they continued to make these post-war, starting with the serial number 476XXX.

This specific guns serial number being 429703 makes this one of the last being pumped out of the factory as the German's were losing the war. The last ditch effort is shown on it's rough slide.

Collector Value:
$400-600 approx.

The XD(M)® 3.8” Compact is the smallest of the XD(M)® line, but it’s by no means the least. It boasts the same superior ergonomics, reliable performance, and features that make larger XD(M)®’s easy and intuitive to use in a slightly abbreviated package. And you’ll be amazed at how fun it is to shoot.
The XD(M)® 3.8” Compact has a 3.8 inch barrel mated with a shortened compact frame. When combined with the versatility of XD(M) Gear® X-Tension™ (USPAT7191556) magazines, the XD(M)® 3.8” Compact is ready for daily carry or a day on the range. Put in an X-Tension™ (USPAT7191556) magazine, and you have a 19 round full-sized 9mm pistol (16 rounds in .40SW, 13 rounds in .45ACP). Use the flush-fitting 13 round magazine, and you have a Compact (11 rounds in .40SW, 9 rounds in .45ACP). Like all XD(M)®’s, the XD(M)® 3.8″ Compact comes with three interchangeable backstraps, dovetail sights, mega-lock frame texturing, an ambidextrous magazine release, a multi-position frame rail, and a match grade barrel.You’ll also find all the safety features that make the XD(M)® a safe pistol in responsible hands.
If you want a gun for daily carry as well as a trip to the range, but you only want to buy one gun, try the XD(M)® 3.8” Compact. You’ll be amazed at how controllable it is to shoot and how easy it is to conceal. It’s two guns in one.

title: For Sale:  Sig Sauer P245 for sale
postcontent:
If you are looking for a concealed carry pistol with massive knock down power and legendary German Engineering then this is the pistol for you!

This predecessor to the P220 was issued primarily to plain-clothed law enforcement, the Sig Sauer P245 quickly acquired a reputation of dependable accuracy, functionality, and ease of concealment.  

The P245 you see here is in perfect working condition and was my primary EDC pistol until recently.  There is holster wear on the slide and a small nick in the anodozing on the beavertail, but other than that it looks great.  The pistol was maintained by a DOJ armorer so the functionality is flawless.

It has been upgraded with Trijicon night sites and two extended magazines.

Also included are two compact magazines, two additional extensions, and a Gould & Goodrich 807 leather concealment holster.

The dimensions are the same as the P220 so you can use P220 grips, magazines, holsters, etc with no loss in functionality.

title: For Sale:  DMW 1906 Commercial Luger 7.65
postcontent: Really cool old Luger.  Came from a collection of a deceased relative. We believe but cannot prove it came back from Germany after WWII. Top of gun has script DMW. Serial number 27,8xx.  See pictures for condition. It is NOT a 9mm. The proofing marks are a crown over the letters B and U on the breech and receiver and the same marks on teh barrel with an additional letter G.  Also on the barrel is the number 17228, making it a 7.65 (.30 cal).  It is an early production for this model.  High retail is $4,000.  Finish is original.  A Luger specialist said to expect 25 to 30% below high retail from a dealer, making it $2,800 to $3,000.  I am asking $2,500.   One thing that makes this more rare is that there is NO EAGLE marking on it, meaning it was only sold in the German market and thus quite rare in the U.S.
